channel.title: BBC News - Home

item.title: Social care: PM to unveil overhaul of sector in England
item.description: Boris Johnson will set out changes to the system, amid a Tory backlash over tax rises to cover costs.

item.title: Afghanistan: Taliban claim to have taken Panjshir Valley
item.description: The Taliban raise their flag over Panjshir Valley, but resistance fighters deny being defeated.

item.title: Justin Trudeau hit by stones on campaign trail
item.description: The Canadian leader's campaign has been disrupted by protesters angry at a planned vaccine mandate.

item.title: The Wire star Michael K Williams found dead
item.description: The 54-year-old died from a suspected drug overdose in his New York flat, media reports say.

item.title: Covid-19: Recovery funding for NHS and hope over post-furlough job cuts
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Tuesday morning.

item.title: Texas abortion clinics will be protected, Justice Department says
item.description: US Justice Department's pledge comes after a near-total ban on abortions took effect in the state.

item.title: Nicola Sturgeon to set out plans for Holyrood year ahead
item.description: Scotland's first minister will announce her "programme for government" for the coming year at Holyrood.

item.title: Planned job cuts fall despite furlough deadline
item.description: August saw the fewest redundancies since 2014 despite plans to end furlough on 30 September.

item.title: BBC's director of news Fran Unsworth to leave the corporation
item.description: Fran Unsworth, who oversees all news and current affairs output, will leave at the start of 2022.

item.title: Police Scotland admits failures over M9 crash death
item.description: The force admits that failures in its call handling system "materially contributed" to a young woman's death.

item.title: Bolsonaro: New bill will limit tech giants' power to remove content
item.description: Brazil's president signs a decree requiring firms to provide "just cause" before removing posts.

item.title: Muppets creator Jim Henson's Hampstead home given blue plaque
item.description: The plaque is on the Hampstead house where Jim Henson lived for more than a decade.

item.title: Australian bush rescue: Mother's reunion with boy lost for four days
item.description: Three-year-old Anthony "AJ" Elfalak is recovering with family after going missing for four days.

item.title: The papers: NHS tax-rise anger and October firebreak plan
item.description: A "manifesto-busting" tax rise to help pay for the NHS is among a mix of stories leading the papers.

item.title: Esports: Why are there so few professional women gamers?
item.description: There are no female players in the top 300 earners in esports, according to research shared with BBC News.

item.title: Recycling: How do you transform old PPE into something new?
item.description: Turning millions of disposable masks and medical waste into new items is one firm's new mission.

item.title: 'Young, black people have to work three times as hard'
item.description: This week sees the launch of a programme making high-flying careers more accessible.

item.title: Inside Big Ben's restoration as it nears finish
item.description: The restoration of Elizabeth Tower, which will ultimately cost at least £80 million, draws to a close.

item.title: Spider season: Why your home might feel full of arachnids right now
item.description: They're not coming through the windows - they were already inside.

item.title: 'Why not have festivals that only women can attend?'
item.description: The idea for the three-day LBTQ Femme Fest was conceived on social media during lockdown.

item.title: Baby Queen: Meet pop's boldest, sharpest new voice
item.description: "I have a problem releasing music that doesn't feel significant," says Bella Latham, aka Baby Queen.

item.title: Why social workers are being embedded in schools
item.description: A new project is embedding social workers in schools. How is it improving family life?

item.title: US Open: Why it is right to be excited about 'wise' & 'fearless' Emma Raducanu
item.description: As British teenager Emma Raducanu reaches the US Open quarter-finals, BBC Sport looks at why it is right to be excited by her journey.

item.title: Climate change: Shetland's power struggle between oil and wind
item.description: The row over plans for a new oil field at Cambo has placed Shetland in the heart of the debate over energy production.

item.title: India jewellery ad starring trans model wins hearts
item.description: The ad is being praised in India where popular culture still portrays transgender people as caricatures.

item.title: Nizar Banat: The death shaking the Palestinian leadership
item.description: The killing of Nizar Banat in Palestinian custody has fuelled rare protests calling for change.

item.title: Why coders love the AI that could put them out of a job
item.description: Artificial intelligence is getting better at penning code but still a long way from working alone.

item.title: Debutant Maguire shines as Europe beat US to retain Solheim Cup
item.description: Europe record just their second win on US soil to retain the Solheim Cup with a hard-fought 15-13 victory in Ohio.

item.title: I should have been banned forever, says online troll who sent racist message to England's Saka
item.description: One racist troll tracked down by the BBC says social media companies should have banned him for longer.

item.title: 'Everyone has the same right to love' - Vettel on speaking out as an LGBTQ+ ally
item.description: Sebastian Vettel made headlines at the Hungarian Grand Prix by wearing a T-shirt in support of LGBTQ+ rights. He tells the BBC's LGBT Sport Podcast why he is taking a stand.

item.title: 'Must-not-lose' for Scotland in Austria, says McGregor
item.description: Scotland's World Cup qualifying visit to Austria is a "must-not-lose game, rather than must-win", according to midfielder Callum McGregor.

item.title: 'I'm going to have nine million death threats' - Rogers speaks out on social media abuse after defeat
item.description: American Shelby Rogers voices concerns about death threats she expects to receive on social media after her US Open fourth-round defeat by Emma Raducanu.

item.title: England v India highlights: Tourists seal fourth Test victory with superb bowling display
item.description: England's batting folds under an inspired spell of bowling from India, who sweep to a 157-run victory on the final day at The Oval to take a 2-1 lead in the series.

item.title: Covid: Will I need a jab and what will university be like this term?
item.description: Many Covid restrictions have been lifted for students going to university this term.

item.title: Covid passports: Nightclubs, concerts and festivals... where will I need one?
item.description: Covid passports to prove vaccination will be required from the end of September in crowded indoor venues in England.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The progress made in vaccinating the country's population, as more than 48 million people have received at least one dose.

item.title: Universal credit: When will the £20 increase stop?
item.description: The government has confirmed the £20 boost will end in the autumn.

item.title: What are the rules and guidance for face masks and coverings?
item.description: Masks are no longer compulsory in England, but remain necessary in other parts of the UK.

item.title: Covid: Which children are being vaccinated and why?
item.description: Millions of children, including 16- to 17-year-olds, are now being offered a Covid vaccine.

item.title: Back to school: How are pupils being kept Covid-safe?
item.description: Many children are returning to school after the holidays, while Scottish pupils already returned.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: How is furlough changing and when will it end?
item.description: The furlough scheme, which protected millions of jobs during the pandemic, is in its final weeks.

item.title: What are the holiday rules for travel to green, amber and red list countries?
item.description: A traffic light system is in place setting out rules for entering the UK

item.title: Afghanistan: Rural areas welcome peace and end of war
item.description: In more rural areas of Afghanistan, people welcome the end of a war that has killed tens of thousands.

item.title: US Senator Lindsey Graham: 'We will be going back into Afghanistan'
item.description: Republican Senator Lindsey Graham believes there will be no choice as "the threat will be so large".

item.title: Afghanistan: Taliban accused of killing pregnant police officer
item.description: The killing comes amid increasing reports of escalating repression of women in Afghanistan.

item.title: Afghanistan: What's life like since the Taliban took over?
item.description: People around the country tell the BBC they have lost basic freedoms and are struggling to survive.

item.title: Afghanistan: Despair of Brits and UK allies stuck behind Taliban lines
item.description: An NHS worker, a teacher and families trapped in Afghanistan tell the BBC about their plans now.

item.title: Afghanistan women's cricket team: Players hiding in Kabul fear Taliban rule
item.description: Members of Afghanistan's women's cricket team are hiding in Kabul, fearing for their safety following the Taliban's return to power.

item.title: British soldier describes caring for Kabul airport baby
item.description: Lt Col Ben Caesar helped look after the baby who was pulled over the airport wall in Afghanistan.

item.title: Life under the Taliban: Where is your male escort?
item.description: Lyse Doucet takes the temperature on the streets of the Afghan capital as the Taliban tighten their grip.

item.title: Kabul drone strike: The key questions about a US attack
item.description: Ten Afghan civilians died when the US targeted a vehicle it says was linked to an imminent bombing.

item.title: Afghanistan: Taliban parade captured equipment in Kandahar
item.description: The militant group showcased the kit captured during their takeover of Afghanistan.

item.title: The hard men removing squatters in Spain
item.description: Some squatters in Spain demand cash before leaving - so eviction firms have arisen to handle the talks.

item.title: Afghanistan: Shukria Barakzai's whispered voice notes and dramatic escape
item.description: The desperate messages sent by Afghan politician Shukria Barakzai to a UK MP as the Taliban tried to hunt her down.

item.title: Afghanistan: The 'undefeated' Panjshir Valley - an hour from Kabul
item.description: The Panjshir Valley has been a flashpoint in Afghanistan's turbulent history - now it's happening again.

item.title: Bilal Sarwary: 'The plane hit the tower and all our lives changed'
item.description: Afghan journalist Bilal Sarwary was selling carpets when 9/11 happened. From that day on, everything changed.

item.title: Shot in the head in Angola, left for dead, now a Wetherspoons star
item.description: Cesar Kimbirima fled Angola after being shot four times and spending five months in a coma.
